body.p: Philadelphia (Pennsylvania) Thursday Heshvan 12th (Nov. 4th) 5596.
To the Rt. Rev. Dr Solomon Hirschel
Grand Rabbi of the Polish & German Jews in London.
Honoured Sir

The eminent station which you occupy has made your name
familiarly known among us, and the fame which attaches to you as
an able expounder of the holy law with which we are blessed naturally
makes you conspicuous to us even who are separated from your residence
by the distance which the great sea interposes. In this country there is none
who is authorized to give an opinion in contested or uncertain points of
law, and we are therefore compelled upon any emergency which arises to
decide for ourselves as best we can, or to ask an opinion of one another,
and as our books for reference are but few, and our knowledge in these
matters not being as extensive as it should be; I have on mature reflec-
tion, and upon the advice of friends, amongst whom I may mention Dr. Mr. Ema
nuel, whom you well know, resolved to place before you several questions for
your decision, and to beg you most earnestly to favour me with your
reply by the earliest possible opportunity, that we may have a certain and
an authentic opinion to go upon in the cases hereafter to be enumerated.
I myself am a native of Westphalia in Germany, whence I emigrated
to this country in the winter of the year 5584 when I was seventeen years old;
I had then a slight acquaintance with ? having gone through בבא מציעא, ביצה
and a part of חולין and בבא בתרא; with the פוסקים I had as yet not meddled, as
of course I was yet too young at that time for so important a study,
and after I reached America I was engaged in business, and had besides
neither books nor teachers to help myself further. It is now about six
years and a quarter since I was elected to serve as חזן to the Portuguese
congregation מקוה ישראל in this place, altho' I can hardly say that I was suffi-
ciently qualified, but owing to there being but few in this country capable at all
for this station the partiality of the people here called me away from Richmond
in Virginia where I had lived five years and a quarter with my uncle, an old gentleman

who had been settled for many years in America. Knowing my own want of
proper qualification I would never have consented to serve, if others more
fitting in point of standing, information or other qualities had been here; but
this not being the case, as is proved by there being yet two congregations at
least in this country without a regular חזן I consented to serve. During the
whole time of my being in office constantly occurrences have taken place
which demanded decisions more complicated than my own information was
able to afford. But having in the neighbouring city of New York a man of
sterling information and a connection of my family by name of Israel B.
Kursheedt, no doubt also known to you by reputation, I occasionally
referred to him. But as he is not authorized in the regular way to give
decisions, and as therefore his opinions are liable to be objected to, I now
address you, as already stated to ask of you, which will without doubt be
a pleasure to you, to assist your brethren in America with your advice and
counsel in their endeavours to worship the God of their fathers in truth.
Perhaps all said hitherto might have been as well omitted, but yet I thought it
best to inform you at once why you are troubled with a letter by one who
is in all likelyhood a perfect stranger to you, for I doubt whether even my
name has ever reached your ears before. In the first place then allow
me to levy a case before you which has recently occurred here, and which
has carried a considerable degree of excitement. You must know that
from a cause or the other things occur here for which it is difficult to
find a parallel elsewhere, and so it happened that a man by name of
Reuben Etting living in Baltimore, where there was no מוהל had a son
born to him about 35 years ago. He sent for a מוהל from Philadelphia
if I am not mistaken, and they alledge that some accident happened
to the child in consequence of the מילה, which however the family of the
מוהל, who has been dead long before I came to America, as strenuously
deny. Be this as it may, three sons born to Etting after that time were
left uncircumcised, the youngest of whom was however circumcised here after
he was old enough to judge for himself. The elder two however are ערלים, and

one of them, named Benjamin was married some years back to the daughter of a
gentleman of Richmond by name of Joseph Marx, highly respected for his wealth
and standing as a merchant. I lately saw in this place the gentleman that
gave them ערלים and he assured me that he did not know that the man
he married was an ערל. Of this however I can not speak with certain-
ty, and I only state it that you may have all the circumstances of the
case as far as known to myself. Benj. Etting had born him two
sons, whom he contrary to the advice of his family, (who are now all
residents in Philadelphia,) left ערלים. In the beginning of the summer
he himself went out on a voyage to Canton in China, and in the mean
time his youngest son sickened and died on the last Sunday in
Elul.
Our congregation was applied to, to permit the child to be buried in our
בית עליון, and by my advice the Parnass permitted it to be done; I conten
ded that the child was מזרע ישראל, and not worse than מומר קטן שהמיר עם אביו או אמו
of whom it is said אין מתבלין עליו, from which I inferred that
a יורה דעה סי שמה סנו' he may have, not being able to find any thing in relation to קבורה
mentioned in the יורה דעה; at the same time I decided that the child should be
looked upon as a קטן שלא הגיע למילה, and that they should give it מילה and call
it a name as it mentioned in reference to a child that dies before it is
eight days old. Dr. Emanuel made the מילה; but because the parents had
been פושעים and having been warned, I refused to attend the לויה, not being
willing to read the תפלות over such a child. Understand me well, venerable
Rabbi, that on no account would I have presumed to have given an opinion,
if there were any body else here to whom I could have applied for advice, and
thus therefore I was compelled to act, as I have done, altho by so doing I
gave offence to those that said the child ought not to have been buried
at all, and others again, and among them the large family connection
of the child, who said I should and ought to have attended the לויה. I
therefore ask now your opinion, upon the following points arising out of this case
a) Is a יהודי ערל allowed to marry a בת ישראל or not?
b) Is a “ allowed to have a מצוה or to be עולה לתורה or not?

c) Is he allowed to come to קבר ישראל, and if he is, what is to be done in case
he is full grown and had had an opportunity to take the מילה on himself?
d) Is he entitled to be buried in the regular row or should he be laid חן הצר?

e) Should the חזן say צדוק הדין over a child like the one spoken of, or had he
better not be at the burial?
f) Should צדוק הדין and the other תפלות be at all said over such a ערל or not?

g) Are the daughters of such a man, born to him by a בת ישראל regular
and חותרות לבא בקהל or not?

On some of these points I have no draft myself, but to satisfy every one
both who agreed with and those who differed from me of what is really the law I
have asked perhaps more questions than were necessary. In case you answer
this be kind enough also to quote the authorities, if there are any to which
we may refer for future decisions, that we may not be compelled to encroach
again upon your valuable time. I forgot to mention that Mr. Reuben Etting
has besides the four sons already mentioned a fifth to whom he gave regularly
the מילה, and so it would appear that he may have been prevented in the other
instances by a fear, however idle, of accidents, which he believed to have
occurred to his eldest son. The whole family was very much distressed at my
absence from the burial, and were of course in a corresponding degree angry,
at what they thought a wanton insult offered at them. However it must
be borne in mind that there are four or five more families here who are
situated in the same way, and as there are at least two grown persons, it
is absolutely necessary that we should have some fixed opinion to go by, that
we may in future avoid giving just offence to anyone, for I believe sin-
cerely if once an opinion has been obtained from you or some other great
teacher in Israel, but especially you, since you are the only one now
in the countries where English is spoken, it will settle the matter for-
ever; since despite of this professed indifference men may feel for religion in
this country still they have sense enough left and virtue enough too to
submit to a ? righteous decision once given, for הרקנים שבך מלאים מצות כרימון

And having ventured thus far permit me to ask you a few other questions.
In this country there are unfortunately many who have married בנות של ניכר
and there are many children descended either by the father or mother's
side from יהודים; you know well what is said קמים גרים לישראל כספחת; still
a great multitude is lost to our people by the great mixture which
has unfortunately subsisted for so many years. I should like therefore
to have a distinct answer to the following question, only premising that
we are in this country permitted to make as many גרים as we please.
I know also that גרים are not likely to be the best יהודים still the confu
sion arising from the number of females particularly who are partly Jews
causes me to lay this question before you for your candid decision and
sincere reflection:

First. Would it be lawful in case a יהודי has married a בת אל זכר to
receive her as a גיורת that the children born from such a union
may be יהודים, or would it be better to leave them go altogether
to destruction, and to refuse them every opportunity of coming again
among us.

You will easily perceive that this matter is of great importance, and
if it would be legalized might prevent much evil. Further, since there
are in this country very often נכריות who are willing to marry יהודים and
become גיורות before hand, whether under the circumstances of the country
it would be right to take them, knowing what their object is in
joining us. Instances indeed have occurred where gentile women
would have been willing to have become Jewesses, and being refused
they still married and they and their children were afterwards
למכשול ולפוקה, since their daughters afterwards married יהודים and so carried
the sin from generation to generation.

Second. In what light are children to be regarded whose father was a Jew and
whose mother a נכרית?

Third. What must be done to children whose mother was a יהודית and whose
father a גוי? are they to be considered as יהודים without טבילה or must they too
have טבילה?

Fourth. Suppose a לוי marries a גויה and they have children, and afterwards the mother
become a גיורת are the children both before her טבילה to be considered as לוים or not?
I myself have decided that they are also גרים and of course not לוים; but
I should like to know whether I was right or wrong?

Fifth. Suppose a יהודית should have children or rather daughters by a גוי are
they מותרות לכהן or not?

Sixth. Would it be right להתחלה to accept as גרים grown persons whose father
was a יהודי and whose mother a גויה?

At the present moment I cannot think of more cases concerning
this point, but be kind enough to write out if you can do it without
too much trouble all the laws relating to this important consideration,
and you will I hope undertake to satisfy us in this country, when I assure
you that there are at least a third of all the American families interested
in it, I refer especially to those that live in Philadelphia. There are
also a number in New York and elsewhere similarly situated, but of
those I cannot speak with as much certainty.

Sometime ago several families from various causes wished
the marriage of their daughters to take place in the morning instead
of the afternoon as usual. The congregation very properly refused
granting their consent to such an innovation. But yet it would give
us much satisfaction to have your decision on this subject also, and
whether a marriage may take place in the morning or not?—

Would a marble basin, hewn out of a solid block, holding a
שעור מקוה filled with water coming by means of fixed machinery from a
river, which water is originally forced up in a reservoir by means
of machine pump be כשר for a מקוה? or would it be considered a כלי and פסול?
bay water brought into a bath built of stone or single bricks cemented by
mortar from a river as above be used for a מקוה or are they considered as מים שאובים?

I should like to ask your opinion upon many other points from time to
time, if you would permit me, to address you occasionally; which I trust
you will grant me, and I assure you, that you still never need blame
yourself for the favour granted. If you can conveniently do it,
please to make your reply in English, that it may be extensively
circulated. Answer this if you can by the earliest packet, since
not I alone but many other persons are anxious for your opinion.

I have seen with pleasure that חזן De Sola has undertaken
a new edition of the Portuguese service, since the books formerly issued
by David Levy ? are not now to be had any more though often inquired
after. Two years ago I wanted to undertake the same labour myself,
but a sever illness, the small-pox, kept me confined for several months,
and my health has ever since continued too bad to permit me to
undertake so heavy a task. Having been thus myself prevented by
the hand of God from accomplishing my design, I am glad to see it under-
taken by one who I hope is fully capable to do justice to the work. If it is
well done, I shall rejoice that it has been accomplished, and shall use
my endeavours, feeble as they are, to forward the author's design. If you
think proper you may communicate this to him, altho' I have never
had the pleasure of hearing any thing about him, till I heard of his
prospectus some weeks since from a bookseller of eminence who belongs
to our congregation, and not till this morning was the prospectus itself
placed in my hands.

I am afraid I have detained you too long, particularly by matters
not relevent to my inquiries, if so I beg you to excuse me; and to
forgive the errors of a stranger, who speaks to a father and teacher
in Israel; whom he would gladly personally see & know. May our
God preserve you many years in health and prosperity, and may there
never be wanting one in your family to sit on the seat of judgment in Israel.
